qas.question: What is commonly contrasted with empiricism?
Where does rationalism say knowledge comes from?
What is an example knowledge being derived from intuition?
What did Locke think some knowledge could come from?
Where were the main European rationalists?
Who were the main philosophical empiricists?
What did John Locke say required information from one's experience?

plausible_answers.text: knowledge may be derived from reason

qas.question: Why are empiricists and rationalists similar?
How did empiricists discover innate ideas?

context: Philosophical empiricists hold no knowledge to be properly inferred or deduced unless it is derived from <b9_0>one's sense-based experience<b9_0/>. This view is commonly contrasted with <a0_0>rationalism<a0_0/>, which states that <b8_0>knowledge may be derived from <a1_0>reason<b8_0/> independently of the senses<a1_0/>. For example, John Locke held that some knowledge (e.g. <a2_0><b6_0>knowledge of God's existence<b6_0/><a2_0/>) could be arrived at through <a3_0>intuition and reasoning alone<a3_0/>. Similarly Robert Boyle, a prominent advocate of the experimental method, held that we have innate ideas. The main <b7_0>continental<b7_0/> rationalists (<a4_0><b5_0>Descartes, Spinoza, and Leibniz<b5_0/><a4_0/>) were also advocates of the empirical "scientific method".
